segments.text: on April 24th with, sorry, what's your first name?
Mr. Menke, or you could say Gary Menke.
Okay, Gary Menke, PhD.
Correct.
Okay.
Over there.
Okay.
Hey, first off, can you just tell me a little background about yourself?
Where were you born, your parents, education, things like that?
Okay.
I was born in Cumberland, Maryland in 1940.
I'm the son of a regional game warden for the state of Maryland.
And my mother was an insurance salesperson, or I guess a secretary that worked in an insurance office.
So I grew up on the East Coast in Maryland.
and went to school at West Virginia University, where I got a master's degree.
And then after my master's degree, I went in the Peace Corps.
And when I came back from the Peace Corps, I went to get a Ph.D. at the University of Missouri.
Okay, so you grew up mostly in Maryland?
Right.
Okay, what were your motives or influences that caused you to join the Peace Corps?
Well, first off, I was intrigued with the idea when the Peace Corps notion first came out.
I guess it was a Hubert Humphrey idea that was caught by Jack Kennedy, and he had a lot of real magnetism and dynamism, and he really invigorated a lot of young people.
And my sister went in the Peace Corps, I guess, in one of the first phases of it.
And she spent two years in Tanzania.
And she was very successful in that operation.
So she decided to re-up for a second two years.
And the time she was going for her second two years, my roommate, Richard Rodman, was
thinking about the Peace Corps.
He was doing some graduate studies at West Virginia University and he went in the Peace Corps and went to Ecuador.
So I was getting letters from Rodman and I was also getting letters from my sister.
And so I was, you know, pretty well plugged into what was going on with the Peace Corps.
So when I graduated with my master's degree, I thought, well, I couldn't really decide whether I wanted to teach or not.
And then came this opportunity to do a university education program that

Bolivia wanted and so I said you know this is a good opportunity to teach actually with the master's degree and then if I decide that you know that's something that I want to pursue as a career that I can go back and get a PhD.
You mentioned about the effect of JFK had on your decision.
Can you expand a little bit on that?
Okay, well Jack Kennedy of course in his
challenge to all Americans to ask not what their country can do for them but what they can do for their country.
I think that people started thinking outwardly and so it was something that challenged all of us and I think it perhaps gave us a little bit more of the zeal to look for new opportunities and
When he was killed, I guess, Lyndon Johnson took over, and that's about the time when I went into the B squad.
Okay.
Did you use these skills you got from your education you were mentioning?
Were you asked to do something that was relative to that, or was it a task totally different from what you were trained to do?
No, I used, of course, all my university education.
It was both a teaching job and using some of the training that I had as a
a geologist.
I had a master's degree in geology with a minor in math.
So I decided to.
And what they wanted at the University of San Andres in La Paz, Bolivia, they were interested in several courses.
And so I taught two geology courses, and I taught a couple of math courses.
to high school students who were preparing for college.
They were getting ready to take their university entrance exams.
And so I taught in a night school English and two math courses to help them in their preparatory to the year.
entrance exams.
Did you speak Spanish before you left?
I had 12 hours of college Spanish, and what we did in the first part of the Peace Corps is that we actually kind of immersed ourselves in Spanish, did about five hours of Spanish a day.
And then we went off to the Olympic Peninsula and actually did some practice teaching in Spanish.
And then as soon as we got in country, it was a little while before the actual school program started.
So for that first six months while we were getting involved in the universities, learning the system, we were also taking private tutor lessons in country.
and living with Bolivian families where we had to continually speak.
So by the time we had to begin teaching in Spanish, we were fairly well prepared.
You mentioned you went to Bolivia.
Where else were you sent in your stay in the Peace Corps?
That was it.
We spent two years in Bolivia.
I say we.
the woman that I eventually married were in the same Peace Corps training program, and so we were both down there together.
Did you all request to go to Bolivia together?
No, we separately were thinking about the Peace Corps and just happened to, I didn't actually know her before Peace Corps training, so we met in
Peace Corps training at the University of Washington in Seattle.
But did you request Bolivia, you personally?
No.
No, it was just I had written to the Peace Corps and said that I would be interested in information about new programs coming out.
And the summer after I got my master's degree, they
wrote to me and said we've got a program just starting up and we're prepared to wire you tickets if you want to join the program.
So it was something I had to make a decision pretty quickly because I also had a summer job lined up with Shell Oil Company that summer and so it was
kind of difficult to make that decision, but it was something that I wanted to do, so I had to cancel one job and quickly change gears and get into the other one.
What year was that that you started?
That was in 1964.
And that was the first year of the Peace Corps?
No, it had started, I think, already in about 1960 or 61.
just after Jack Kennedy took office.
So I think it was perhaps 60 or 61 that it really started.
So I was in the sort of the second or third bunch of Peace Corps volunteers.
Had already been one group of Peace Corps volunteers in Bolivia by the time we got there.
Was there any other reason that motivated you to join?
Did you get draft deferment by doing this, or anything like that?
Well, I was not assured that you would have draft deferment.
At that time, there was some buildup of, actually, we hadn't started building up in Vietnam yet, because that was during the first years when Johnson took over.
We did have advisors over there, and it was not certain whether people were going to get deferments for being in Peace Corps service.
Certainly if you didn't make the program, I mean, it was not assured just when you went into Peace Corps training.
that you were going to be able to make the grade and actually be what they were looking for.
So obviously, if you didn't succeed in the training program and you weren't selected to do your in-country work, then of course you would lose any chance of having a deferment.
But that wasn't a motivating factor.
It was just something that...

The opportunity came at the right moment for me just after I graduated and actually had to, like I say, decide not to take a summer job with an oil company, which was a very interesting one and would have been an also exciting thing to do.
What was your relationship like with your locals and how did you find the culture?
Well, we took some Bolivian cultural training at the University of Washington.
We had actually some Bolivians there.
We had a lot of Latin Americans that were on the staff.
And we had some Mexicans, some Argentines, and some Bolivians, and some Ecuadorians that were
part of the instructors in the training program.
And of course, they helped us to prepare what the country was going to be like, what the culture was going to be like.
And of course, you're never fully prepared.
But I think when we first got there, the biggest distraction was that a revolution very quickly broke out.
president of the country, Victor Paz Estensoro, at the time was required to actually leave the country for his own protection and there was a lot of heavy fighting that went on.
And so that also slowed down our initial involvement in the country because
There were some snipers inside the university, and the university got machine guns several times.
And there was a lot of damage that had to be repaired and a lot of political turmoil that had to be quelled and calmed down before things went back to normal.
So it kind of made it a difficult situation to start into.

and there was also a curfew that was put on, so you couldn't get around too much in the evenings, and so it made it a little more difficult to actually see the city, and you had to do everything during the daytime hours.
And you were in La Paz, is that right?
Uh-huh, in La Paz.
What about with the locals in the city?
How did they treat you?
We were treated generally with pretty much respect.
We lived with the Bolivian family and I think they were curious about Americans and so I think they wanted to learn as much about us as we wanted to learn about them.

And it was also very helpful because when we had difficult questions to ask them about anything that was happening in the culture, how should we react to different situations, we could just go and explain it to them, and they would be almost like our foster guardians, and they could kind of tell us the best way to act or the best way to handle the situations.
So I think that was, you know,
good for both sides.
You mentioned the difference in culture that you'd have to go and ask them about.
What were some of the customs that you found kind of strange or different from the local customs you were familiar with?
Just for example.
Well, let's see.
I think

A lot of the things that you're not quite used to, like, for example, when just something that you want to get in line for a bus, get onto a bus, or if you want to go to a movie, it's our culture that we go, we stand in line, everything is orderly.
Sometimes this doesn't happen.
In places like Bolivia, you get there and you find out that the way to form a waiting group for your ticket is to be in a semicircle and everybody reaching around.
And so this is kind of annoying and disturbing to somebody who doesn't understand the culture.
It's something, I guess, that we got to learn to get used to.
You don't want to generate confrontations out of these things.
At the same time, you don't want to just stand back and, you know, feel like that you're not going to get your fair opportunity to do things.
So that was certainly one instance.
The teaching role itself, I think there's a lot of, I wouldn't call them necessarily discipline problems, but they certainly do like to challenge the teachers and professors, and particularly if they

feel that you're somewhat of a curiosity then you know they may decide to do things like call boycotts of classes and then when you confront them about you know why they did this well you know they would come up with some kind of excuse like well there's American involvement in the Dominican Republic and so
We're protesting.
Now, mind you, we don't have anything against you personally, but we're kind of just trying to demonstrate against that kind of thing.
So you never knew whether it was a serious thing or whether they were just taking advantage of the situation.
So these were the things that we...
We had to learn how to deal with them.
It was mainly through talking to your counterparts in the university and other professors and say, what should we do?
How should we handle it?
So that's basically some of the differences, I guess.
What did they say when you asked the department?
Well, a lot of times, they realized
You know, there are these times when political activism does take over.
And like I said, there had just been a revolution.
So everybody was a little bit on tender hooks and didn't want to really stir up more activity than they thought was necessary.
We're just going to have to learn to maximize the time we do have with the students.
If we create an environment where they think that it's valuable to come to class, then they will.
So I think that's what we try to do.
I guess it worked out.
Did you find any friction between the Spanish Catholics and the indigenous peoples, the Indians?
As far as I could recognize, I guess the only real conflicts probably were not between people that weren't Catholics necessarily, but they did have what they called the evangelicals.
And these would be some of the other missionaries that are doing work there.
And most of the Indians that we were involved with were actually converted to Catholicism.
There were sometimes some
I suppose you would say competition between the various missionary groups that were working there.
But as far as we could tell, there was never any real hostility that came about because of religions.
there were a few Catholics that were in our Peace Corps group, and others were, you know, I guess different religions, and it really never seemed to be an issue.
Okay.
What was your daily routine like?
Daily routine was, I guess, pretty much the same as a

routine for any professor in the U.S. We were preparing lesson plans and we would I guess one thing that was kind of different is they had kind of a practice of taking their little early morning breaks, well not necessarily early morning, but generally sometime around 10 o'clock they would take some kind of

our coffee break, we'd call it a coffee break, and there they would take some time out to have what they called the saltinas, which were kind of little empanadas, and then they would have their drink, which they called api, which is kind of like a purple corn, hot corn drink.
And so it was kind of unusual, but we got to really liking this little break that we would take at about 10 o'clock.
And you'd sit in a little cafe or something, and then you could talk about different situations.
And it's almost like going into a faculty lounge or something like that.
The difference was that after your classes were over, La Paz is actually at about 12,000 feet.
So it gets really quite cool in the evenings.
And you found out that there was no central heat in the houses.

there wasn't a lot of refrigeration space or anything like that so you wound up basically going to the open markets after your classes were over and you had to buy your food that you were going to prepare for your evening meal and generally you just kind of lived from
buying for that day or maybe for the morning or the next day.
So you sort of bought food for about two days at a time and you didn't have really any way to preserve it or store it.
So you sort of bought in limited quantities and used it quickly.
And then of course you would start to work on your
either grading papers or preparing for next day's teaching assignment.
Sometimes you would also be teaching night classes.
So we had these high school kids from Tupac Atari night school that were preparing for college entrance exams, which they called the cursos visticulares.
And so we would
get ready to go over and teach them.
Also, we had some blind girls, the Ciegitas, which they were sort of personal friends of one of the people that we met there.
And so we decided to go over and spend some time with them.
They were actually quite good singers.
And as it turns out, later on when we got married, as kind of paying us back for the time that we spent, they actually came and sang at our wedding.
And so we had a recording of their singing at our wedding.
It was really pretty special to us.
That's a good transition, because my next question was, what was it like being married in the Peace Corps?

Well, I guess being married in the Peace Corps is like being married anywhere, but certainly it was a very different situation to be married in a big Latin American church where you knew very few people, and yet the church was actually packed.
We had the whole square that was filling up, and the buzz word was going around that there was a gringo wedding that was going to take place.
And so when it came time to actually have the wedding ceremony, the whole church was filled.
This was a church that was a big, high vaulted church with a very ornate altar and everything.
The floor of the church was actually dirt.
It was a dirt floor.
In the tape of the wedding, you could actually hear some of the people sucking on oranges or some of them might be nursing children or whatever.
So it was really quite a different setting for a wedding.
And, of course, most of the ceremonies there were all, of course, in Spanish, so that also made it quite different.
But La Paz, you know, being very high, surrounded by mountains with snow-capped peaks, and it's a really very picturesque-type setting, and, of course,
It's just something very special to us to have all these sort of very different kinds of memories about our early experiences there.
Are we going to say something?
Well, of course.

Being married in a foreign country and not having all the conveniences that you would have if you were starting off in the U.S., I guess it made it more challenging because just for simple things like cooking,
It was quite challenging to prepare a meal on just two little hot plate burners, not having any storage facilities, and then simple things like taking a bath with really no hot water.
You had to heat the water on the stove and then mix in a bucket with cold water to get it sort of warm.
And then you splash that on yourself in order to take baths.
So that was certainly a challenging thing.
Most young people just getting married would probably find that kind of living rather challenging too.
Did either of your parents find?
No.
We have no one from either one of our families that was there.
That was one of the things, I guess, that also made it more of an isolated thing.
We did send them the tape of our wedding ceremony, which I guess was something.
But still, other than the pictures and the tape, they had to certainly experience it all vicariously from our accounts of it.
Were they very upset about that?
It wasn't like you eloped or anything?
No, I guess they realized that both of us were doing things that they probably wouldn't have considered at the time when they were growing up.
To go off and go to a foreign country and to get married in that foreign country and so forth.
I guess was probably pretty foreign to try to actually plan to go and attend the wedding.
I guess it was probably more than we could arrange.
Certainly my parents would never think of getting on an airplane and flying to a foreign country.
So I guess that was just kind of out of the question.
Y'all had your first child when you were in the Peace Corps.
Yes, our first child, David, was born at the end of our Peace Corps term there.
So shortly after, he was born in April, I guess, and our Peace Corps two-year period ended in, I think it was September?
I guess it was June.
And so we just had a few months there where we were also.
But it was kind of interesting.
My wife, Joy, was pregnant at the time she was finishing her teaching assignment at the University of La Paz, or San Andres in La Paz, Bolivia.
It just turns out that the day that she turned in her final grades for the classes, I guess the baby was born the next day.
So I guess that was pretty good timing.
What were the hospital facilities like?
Well, the hospital facilities were certainly, I guess you would say, challenging.
She had the baby.
which is a very little missionary hospital.
There was one missionary doctor there.
It was Dr. Thompson, I think.
